summary: In Asenso v. Nkyidwuo, the West African Court of Appeal upheld the reallocation of stool land from the defendant to the plaintiff after the defendant, a stranger to the Juaben Stool, refused to enter into a tribute agreement and neglected the land for over ten years. The court found that the defendant's conduct constituted abandonment, justifying forfeiture and re-granting of the land under customary law. It affirmed that Native Courts may admit documentary evidence that materially clarifies disputes, even if inadmissible in higher courts. The appeal was dismissed, affirming the plaintiff's valid customary tenancy.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; original grant to plaintiff upheld

jurisdiction.court: West African Court of Appeal, Gold Coast Session

citations: Sarbah, Fanti Customary Law, 1st ed., p. 56
Amuabimaa and Another v. Badu and Others (1956) 1 W.A.L.R. 227
rationaleHighlights: Refusal to enter into tribute agreement + long-term neglect = abandonment
Stool entitled to reallocate land after abandonment
No strict rules of evidence in Native Courts
Abandonment may be inferred from conduct over time
Documentary evidence admissible if materially relevant
Customary law must be reasonably applied, not applied sweepingly
Stranger grantees must comply with lawful stool demands
Tenure rights not preserved indefinitely without engagement
